commentBody: I'm not a big fan of anagrams, but this puzzle won me over. Terrific theme cluing. Got the idea with 23A, thought 39A was sweet, and loved the other spanner (117A). The other three were fun too. Between grasping the themers quickly and racing through (what I found to be the) very easy fill clues, I was done almost too quickly, but not so quickly that I missed the callout to Andrezj at 31A. I'm glad Sam made it to The Times; I'd love to see a more challenging puzzle from him.
OK, whose mind was in the gutter with the clue about cup sizes?

"Do you have the gift of GAB?"
"Meh. It's kind of a mixed bag."

(I got that one from my friend Anna Graham.)
Loved the Faux Gardener clue.  That was very clever.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/05/31/sunday-june-1-2025/#ny
I love anagrams and this one did not disappoint!
This was absolutely brilliant.

Nice one, again. 
Anagrams---almost like home!  And these were well found, unforced phrases. Applause.
So it was a shame I didn't puzzle out the theme until I'd filled most of the themers. Picked it up with SWITCHED GEARS, and only had TWISTED SISTER left to fill, so not much help, but still a pleasant Aha!

My command of "currencies of the world" has been paying off of late, though I had two attempts to get the correct spelling of RIEL, which still doesn't look right.
Last to fall was the P at the cross of COMP and PREK. The latter unknown, the former never (I think) encountered as a verb, but guessable.

ODIE, the dog, and SARA Lee, whoever she may be, known only from what feels like frequent exposure in previous puzzles. 

[Author's assistant] cluing TYPIST was like a little visit from the 1930s, but it made me smile.
That was fun! I chortled when I got TWISTEDSISTER.
Fun one, congrats on 1st NYT puzzle!

When I see ROYAL PERMIT my inner anagram alarm goes off. (It sounds like this: ‚ÄúArugula! Arugula!‚Äù)

Fortunately, real phrases like ‚Äútemporarily out of order‚Äù came to my aid, so I didn‚Äôt have to struggle with ‚Äúportlier yam out of order‚Äù or ‚Äúmorality rep out of order‚Äù!
You people that are good with anagrams would have no problem with a morality rep, I‚Äôm sure.

I love the wit of this puzzle, the 'ah ha' when I figured out the scrambled words, and that the answers all seemed natural.  I did not need any cheats, a treasured rarity on a Sunday.  But, oh, did I ever have a typo.  I couldn't find it, even though I combed the answer pdf along with the puzzle three times.  Finally, the spouse had to sit at the computer chair and.... viola!  I had 'play' for 'PLAN', somehow I didn't see the wrongness of 'bowiyg'!  

I hope to see many more such puzzles from Sam Brody!

Hey, kids!

Are there any Elks out there? 

The June issue of The Elks Magazine includes a feature article on the history of crossword puzzles. I was surprised to see that the NTY was a relative latecomer to publishing crosswords, only agreeing to publish them once WWII began, mostly to provide a diversion for anxious people during "blackout hours" when they were supposed to hunker indoors with the drapes closed. 

Once the puzzles became a daily feature in the 1950s, the first NYT puzzle editor, Margaret Petherbridge Farrar, supposedly instituted the progression in difficulty during the week, from easiest on Monday to most difficult on Saturday. But I have seen many people who comment here say it was a policy instituted by Shortz. I have been working through the archives and I do not see any progression in difficulty in the older puzzles. Is this perhaps because the policy was suspended at some point and re-instituted by Shortz, or is the article wrong about this? 

Any clarification? 

Anyway, I thought I'd de-lurk to mention that the article is out there and also to ask this question that popped into my head when I read it. 

Carry on.

my son and i loved the subtle wit of the anagrams, and many of them made me chuckle out loud. (lucky for me, my son's younger brain is much better at anagrams than i am!) i agree with barry and others that the rest of the puzzle was a bit easier than a usual sunday, but i find that is often the case when the theme is particularly clever. i can accept that trade-off every now and then.

i'm glad to hear sam has had two more puzzles accepted by the nytimes, and i look forward to solving many more of his creations in years to come!

Very clever, quite tricky. I'm not crazy about puzzles with anagrams but this one won me over. The faux gardener clue was fun, "what you will" was funny and Etsy/Ebay had me going for a while. Good puzzle.
Fun, and not all that hard -- hey, didn't we deserve a break after yesterday?

A puzzle full of MIXED BLESSINGS‚Äîclues I knew fills for and crosses that OPENed DOORs to untangle my errors.  A solid, enjoyable puzzle, just hard enough to be engaging, clever enough to be challenging, and fun to work.  

Thanks, Sam Brody, and welcome to the Times.

Ananagraphia (n.):
The inability to see or appreciate anagrams.

:-(
Pretty good. I like anagrams
Truly elegant. I love puzzles that gradually unfold, where an inkling of the theme starts to emerge and then ‚Ä¶ aha!

Great debut Sam Brody! No bones about it. Guess who holds the Guinness World Record for the most broken bones? ‚ò†Ô∏è Yep, an estimated 433 bone fractures. https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/most-broken-bones-in-a-lifetime Evel Knievel Museum will re-open in downtown Las Vegas this year!
Why does the 127A clue include "briefly" ?
Loved this theme.  Lovely twists and great cluing.

Fun puzzle!! I'm not a natural anagrammer, so it took me a minute or two after getting MIXEDBLESSING from context to understand it, but when I did, I quickly became a big fan! It helped me sail through the rest of the themers, since I had a lot of crosses. Really cute theme!!  Great debut!

The trouble I had was keeping iVaN in for too long at 10D. I don't know the movie but I could have sworn there was an Ivan in it. Getting GENETICALLYENGINEERED fixed me right up, which was good as I at 10A was not helpingful. I think I'll change the ole "There is no I in team to "There is no I in SVEN or STEAD." I already get a lot of odd looks, so why not push the envelope a bit. Har!

Especially enjoyed the clues for EDIT, DORM, and ESTATE. 

I do wish the app had a submit button instead of automatically either giving you a gold star or a mistake message. Often, I feel like I want to revisit an area before considering it my final answer.

In this case, I had SrGT at 92A, which didn't make sense for the down but sometimes I don't see why an answer is what it is at first so I wanted to look at it again. Also, I was pretty sure I had ADENINE right but when I happily entered SWITCHinGEARS, it changed. I corrected them easily when I got the horse feathers message but I would have felt better if I had a chance to revisit those areas that were iffy before I finished. 

No big but in my IDEAL world, there would be a submit button.... And a lot of tacos to scarf, snarf, and/or bolt down.  üòâ
Ooh, I enjoyed decoding the theme a lot!
Fun theme /and/ fun fill? A rare Sunday W

I enjoyed this puzzle a lot, loving the anagrams although I am terrible at them.  

Once in sixth grade after being humiliated several times at my inability to see any anagram solutions at all, I tried to trip up the class by presenting what I hoped would be simple to the point of confusion: "rohse".  

Every hand in the class flew up, and I was...well...let's say I've never been on a horse.
An actual NYT  Sunday crossword puzzle. I really enjoyed it and I sort of wish that I would've waited til tomorrow morning to do it, like in the old days.
Anagrams got me like: https://youtu.be/QhmtXpWsAdU Anybody else feel like Lisa?
I especially loved the fresh hints esp 30 across. 72 down I was thinking Wacoal or Warner! :D. It was clear to me that this was a new puzzle constructor. Looking forward to more in the future!

Re: 82 down, the notion of an ALPHAMALE being the leader of a pack is inaccurate. (Which I'm sure toxic right-wing influencers would be disappointed to learn, if they bothered to read.) Wolf packs are highly social and decisions and responsibilities are shared at least by the top breeding pair. The Alpha FEMALE is often the one who makes decisions about when the pack should move and where they should go. Bloody battles for supremacy are very rare among wolves in the wild. There's a Yellowstone park ranger named Rick McIntyre who has written some absolutely riveting books on the subject, for anyone interested. The Rise of Wolf 8: Witnessing the Triumph of Yellowstone's Underdog https://g.co/kgs/azudrJp

I had SWITCHEsGEARS which tripped me up and I had to come to the column to peek (luckily Caitlin had that one first). 

Did I lose my streak? No! I keep my gold star for Silly Typos and Naticks I Didn't Notice. Those are my Personal Streak Rules and we all have our own rules which is Totally Allowed because "It's Your Puzzle"! And your streak! 

(In case anyone was wondering what the "rules" are. We all get to make them up) üåü
A pleasant diversion while I watch the Dodgers pummel the Yankees.
Well, it was fun, but left me feeling a bit lopsided - still looking for that other legwarmer, dontchaknow.
fun puzzle. 10/10 loved it
solved in my usual hour.  had no clue about anagrinds.  got them all mostly on a combo of crosses and hang-man.  after anagrinds have been explained to me, they make me yawn.

Congratulations on your debut Mr Brody.   NYT Sunday crossword puzzles with anagrams always remind me of a lazy Sunday morning over 40 years ago when I was a student in New York. I had just moved into a shared apartment, and a couple of my roommates were working on the Sunday puzzle, which had an anagram theme much like today‚Äôs. After I (politely, of course) suggested a couple of (incorrect, I should add) answers to clues they were discussing, they asked me to join in the solve.  It was start of some great friendships and I‚Äôve been doing the NYT crossword ever since.

The Times seems to publishing the next days puzzle earlier and earlier.  Late Monday afternoon I started what I thought was Monday's puzzle.  It turned out it was Tuesday's puzzle.  Weekday puzzles used to be available at 7:00 p.m. Pacific time.  Early this afternoon I thought I was starting Saturday's puzzle, only.to realize half way through that it was Sunday's puzzle.  Sunday puzzles used to be available in the late afternoo 

There used to be more consistent timing of when the next day's puzzle is released.  Now it seems to be whenever the hell they feel like it.  Tuesday's puzzle seemed a bit meaty for a Monday puzzle.  This doeant even take into account a typo in one of Tuesday's clues about Lake Erie.  Sunday's puzzlewas definitely meatier than a Saturday puzzle.

The haphazard timing of the publishing schedule takes a lot of the fun out of solving the puzzles.  At this  point, I've given up in trying to solve the Sunday puzzle.  It was too much of a curve ball for a relaxing Saturday afternoon.
Easily finished this puzzle without ever understanding the ‚Äútrick‚Äù  of the anagram.  Quite superfluous and a waste of time‚Ä¶
ADENINE crossing ALOHA OE was pretty darn tough. I had ADaNINE and ALOHA Oa as my last fix before success.

Things I never can remember:

* whether it's Evel or Eval (I always want to put Evil but I know that's not right)
* whether it's Odie or Opie
* that it's 'oe and not 'o√≠ for the song
* the last letter of Mr Rubik's first name 

Hmmm.

Though speaking of BOWING, I'm a bit late doing this puzzle because I was at a concert tonight -- SF Symphony with Hilary Hahn on violin (*not* fiddle lol). Most excellent.
I am terrible at anagrams. And loved this puzzle.

I found this hard hard hard. So many misdirects and I‚Äôm terrible at anagrams. But it was fun with lots of aha moments. 

It makes me wonder if my brain is ossifying in old age. üôÑ
My favorite kind of Sunday puzzle--beautifully constructed, cleverly but fairly clued, with delighted ahas at each reveal.  Thank you, Sam Brody!

Delightful, especially after yesterday's.
I keep forgetting some US usage, like TAD, PRE K, airport codes, and spelling PLOWS for ploughs. 

I like the cute clues like WARES, POLE, DOE, DIAPERS which are not just synonyms. 
I don't understand DORM?

Lovely.
Very nice Sunday puzzle, solid theme and some fun misdirect clues
Altogether satisfying puzzle for my taste.  Always happy to get a Sunday with no look-ups.  Had to work for it, though.

Executive summary:

Much NECTAR, constructor has nothing to RECANT.






Et tu, emu.

Loved it. Good long workout for me, of course, but finally tumbling to the trick was a HUGE turning point and that is always a great touch.

And just one amazing piece of construction. Coming up with all of those anagrams (two grid-spanners!) had to be one long piece of work for the constructor. Just really something. 

Two thumbs way, way up. 

And... puzzle find of course. Very similar kind of trick. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
Congratulations on your NYT debut, Sam.  Very impressive.  All six themers were very much in the language, and yet four appeared for the first time today.  Well done!
My smooth ride was briefly interrupted today when the chain fell off my derailleur as I was confidently SHIFTING GEARS, but I was only TEMPORARILY OUT OF ORDER.

This was fun.

Easy to identify the themers, so I just skipped them until I had something to work with.

Done in time to go out to breakfast with family. I can report to my granddaughters that I first guessed OLAF for 10D. With the number of times I've watched that with them, you'd think I'd have the characters down.

Also first guessed YUMA for 115D.

Some great off-kilter clues, like [Northwestern abode], [Inflation meas.], and [Aid-de-camp].

Thanks!

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	Sweet backstory, where after the thirteenth NYT rejection, Sam doesn‚Äôt tuck his tail and slink away; rather, he grits his teeth, forges on, and three acceptances follow.  Uber inspiring.
‚Ä¢	Enjoyed the fauna (DUCK, PIGS, ANT, WOLF, WREN), not to mention the clues based on ‚ÄúDucks in a row‚Äù and ‚ÄúWhen pigs fly‚Äù.
‚Ä¢	Thoroughly charmed, and that‚Äôs saying something, because I don‚Äôt see anagrams easily. But the theme answers were so solidly in-the-language and fun to guess at I was wowed rather than cowed.
‚Ä¢	Remarkable finds in GENETICALLY ENGINEERED and TEMPORARILY OUT OF ORDER. Furthermore, these are very worthy answer debuts not only in the Times, but in all the major crossword outlets.
‚Ä¢	Terrific never-before-used clues: [Center of mass?] for CHURCH, and [Faux gardener, so to speak] for SCARECROW.

I, who adore language quirks, loved this theme.  Bravo and thank you, Sam, and congratulations on your NYT debut!

That was quite he workout, as I‚Äôm hopeless at anagrams, puns and the like. My brain just will not see them.
Despite that this was so enjoyable. I got the anagrams without knowing that‚Äôs what they were and figured Caitlin would explain it to me at the end.
Tough clues today; 22A crossing 18D, both unknowns. Ditto 104A crossing 94D. I could go on. So many TILs!
This was a lovely debut Sunday puzzle.  Although the themed clues were scrambled, the puzzle itself was an unMIXEDBLESSING.
I really wanted GENETICALLY MODIFIED once I caught on, but one of the more enjoyable Sundays in a while
Loved this. Challenging and rewarding. Loved 71D 'What you will' and also appreciated all the fauna. Wonderful puzzle!
Aloha oe, sweet adenine. A twisted earworm. Aloha oe https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y1bIxMYPlas the Mills Brothers https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zz8yNa4uZN0

Forgot to ask last night:

In what kind of minimalist "obstacle" course is a CONE an element?
Or:
What kind of CONE are we actually talking about, here?
CRUCIVERBA ARS MAGNA
#62 Across is incorrect.  Army NCO abbreviations are only three letters long.  The abbreviation for Staff Sergeant in the Army is SSG, not SSGT.  A Staff Sergeant in the Air Force is SSGT.

I haven‚Äôt done the puzzle yet but here are the banned words, if you scroll down this site, that a previous Sunday‚Äôs Doonesbury alluded to but then the QR code link had disappeared. I am shocked at some of these and some I don‚Äôt even know that well if I know them! https://pen.org/banned-words-list/

Fun puzzle, because it

HELD TO THE OLD SWITCHEROO.

No mixed blessings, here.

I love this type of theme.
You get one, and then your brain
goes into theme-mode, 
arranging and rearranging letters so
that by the second half, you see
the jumbled word and immediately 
know the phrase!

Fantastic.
A spot-on Sunday with
ARUGULA, one of my favorite words.
Because I *cannot* say it without
sounding like an old-timey car horn.

Thank you Sam!
31 across with no question mark is one of my favorite clues ever!

aloha "what!"

Other than not knowing the good bye song, a tough solve but fun.

Thank you Sam

A satisfying puzzle.  The theme was certainly very doable and some of the wordplay was nicely done.
Clues for DORM and EDIT particularly come to mind.

Congrats on your debut Mr Brody!

I figured the theme had something to do with anagrams since it said making ARRANGEMENTS. I am a little embarrassed to admit that I never completely figured out the theme, other than knowing it was some type of anagram, even after recognizing HEART anagrams to EARTH the clue for 39A‚Ä¶ ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è 

However, for me, the rest of the puzzle was relatively easy and I heard the lovely tune after I entered the last letter.

Some minor delays in the SE corner mainly because my brain insisted that 103D was OGRE since they seem to make it into so many puzzles. üòÇ 

Fun Sunday to me. Challenging but solvable (even without being on the same wavelength.
Great puzzle! Loved the unscrambling‚Äî

I will take a break from my usual griping about overly-complex themes to praise this puzzle, despite its difficult (for me) theme. No, it did not help me solve the puzzle, but once I saw what it was doing I was actually somewhat delighted. Very enjoyable solve.

Wow, Sam.  
Tour de Force!  Stellar Performance.  Magnum Opus.
Plus, thanks for recognizing the contribution of yet another unsung heroine of Science at 44A.  (BTW did anyone ELSE see that MTG has said Federal employees weren't doing "real jobs."  Uplifting. Insightful.  So glad she's on the job, there.)

I am not really "up on" the components of DNA--discoveries and subjects that didn't come up during my years of schooling, including college and graduate programs.  You don't necessarily pick up that much even reading news magazines, Smithsonian, etc.  So it was just lucky that I decided SWITCHES should be SWITCHED in order to get something that looked more "sciency" at 95 Down.....  I do recall a group of students at our DR table, constructing a DNA molecule out of colored beads and wire...but they never mentioned what the different colors represented.  I'd have to ask PhysDau if it was for chemistry, biology, or what...

Enough rambling. I am needed at the SEWing machine; I've just UNstitched 13 blocked after putting them together wrong.....arrgh.
Loved today‚Äôs puzzle, especially the themed clues. I especially liked the clueing, no arcane words or proper nouns. I look forward to more such puzzles

Very fine debut!

Got the anagram theme quite early, and then filled in the remaining thematic entries very quickly. TWISTEDSISTER went in instantaneously.

Enjoyed this one a lot, and finished it much more quickly than usual for a Sunday. 

Hardest for me was COMP/PREK. Have never seen COMP before---even if Barry soon informs me it has previously appeared nineteen times  ;-). Fortunately, I knew PRE-K.

Congrats on the debut.
Nice one üôÇ
Such delightful word play...excellent puzzling Sam!  Look forward tor more from you.

Desirable formation for ducks - ROW
So sweet and silly. 
A second look at the theme answers revealed that more was going on than I first thought. 
Nice puzzle.

Exactly right for a Sunday puzzle. 

I picked up the theme with GLIBNESS: ‚ÄúMixed Blessing.‚Äù After that the puzzle went much more smoothly. I won‚Äôt say that it went faster because I hate the emphasis on speed.

Thank you, newbie!

Anyone who likes anagrams might enjoy a web-based version of a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs free to play and has no ads ‚Äî that I created called ‚ÄúStrudel‚Äù (which began as a board game) which can be found at: https://strudel.fringemedia.io/ If you go there, you will have to create a username and password, but you won‚Äôt have to remember them if you stay logged in from the same device. The first time you visit you will get a brief tour of the features. (I will leave you to guess why I chose the name ‚ÄúStrudel‚Äù.)
Excellent puzzling!

"Conversely, if you love this puzzle and haven‚Äôt discovered the joys of cryptics yet, consider it a sign and seek some out."

Does this mean the Times is finally going to make their cryptics available in the app? Or is this just another tease about what we pay for but don't have.

Cute puzzle, but my god how I dislike flyspecking Sundays. ADEtINE crossing with tSA took me 15 minutes to find. My own fault, of course, but I pity the innocents I'm going to be interacting with for the rest of the day, as I struggle not to be growly.
People look forward to Sunday puzzles.  Do better.

SCARECROW = CROWS CARE!

and TOTO TOOT!

Terrific puzzle, comments below already captured the great majority of the fun.

For me ERG as a piece of work with BTU got a laugh out loud.  Thanks Sam!

Off topic, but for those who lament the retirement of Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon as constructors of NYT acrostics, the Times‚Äôs acrostics are currently in the hands of an excellent pair of puzzle creators, Balton and Stewart.  B And S also curate an excellent blog about their acrostics at nytacrostics.com.  I recommend both the acrostics and the blog, for those who love acrostics.
Really well done. I didn't catch on to the theme until very late, but in hindsight, worth the struggle.

What a fun Sunday puzzle! Not exactly difficult but a challenge nonetheless. Took me 20 minutes. 

Caught on to the theme at MIXEDBLESSING. 

Enjoyed the theme and the puzzle overall.

This was the most fun I've had in a while, and it felt perfect for a Sunday! I uncovered the theme about half way through, which made things a bit easier (and more fun). Thanks for a fun puzzle, Mr. Brody, and keep making more!
Really enjoyed this one. Great anagrams. Reminded me of one of my all time favourite clues GEGS where the answer was SCRAMBLED EGGS.
Great puzzle. I was thrown by the mix of tenses in RAGES and SWITCHED GEARS; I had SWITCHES GEARS for far too long. Obviously knowing ADENINE is the work-around, but alas, I am not a biochemist.
I was flummoxed by the theme until I solved CHANGEOFHEART, then the puzzle went much more smoothly. Although overconfidence lead to some consternation with ‚ÄúswitchingGEARS‚Äù for a bit.

IDEAL puzzle for a Saturday if you‚Äôre willing to TAKEASTAB at a SLEW of difficulty and misdirection. Once you‚Äôve figured out the theme, the crossings will help you solve with EASE. Had to look up a few clues after I solved it (OBLASTS, ADENINE, ALOHAOE, DREI) but Saturdays are supposed to be ATAD hard. Wouldn‚Äôt TWEAK a thing.

Very nice Sunday puzzle, with some difficult clues but fairly spread with crossers so as to be gettable. Plenty of nice wordplay as well.
I got stuck at the end for about 10 minutes with BTa and ARaGULA - I call it rocket but thought I remembered the other version of the name. Had no idea about BTU.
Good work, thanks Sam!

Really enjoyed the solve. An interesting variation on my usual experience that I did not notice until checking over everything before filling the last square for the solve. And that is--drum roll--I had actually heard of every answer in this puzzle except for the Hawaiian song, and of course I knew all but the last two letters of that.

This doesn't mean I remembered these answers. Far from it. It means that after filling in each one, I realized I had heard of it somewhere. OBLASTS. I have no idea where I've seen that, but once I got most of the letters, the rest of them emerged from the murk of memory, as with a Magic 8 Ball. And DREI. I have no idea which number that is, but I am guessing that it is less than ten and probably German. And I know that I have seen it before.

None of this made the puzzle easy or quick. I found it satisfyingly crunchy for a Sunday. Could not for the life of me figure out the anagram of LEGAL NICETY, so the NW was the last to fall.

I'm surprised no one yet has pointed out the synchronicity of NO-BRAINER and SCARECROW: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=ZuMbJsjy-zg&pp=ygUidGhlIGNvY29udXRzIGlmIGkgb25seSBoYWQgYSBicmFpbg%3D%3D Whoops! Wrong cover! https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=nauLgZISozs&pp=ygUVaWYgaSBvbmx5IGhhZCBhIGJyYWlu
Great puzzle! A real treat for people using iPads now that the electronic version of puns, anagrams, and cryptic are no longer available. Thanks to the setter for the treat.
Very enjoyable! Great wordplay, and I especially appreciated the nod to my alma mater once I figured out 51A :-)

I love anagrams, so this was a real treat. As soon as I finished, I started in on the puzzle's title, thinking there might be a bonus. So far, I've got ANAGRAM KING, which is fitting, but that leaves me with TREMENS, which is unfortunate. I'll let you know if I find a better solution.

The Northwestern (University) DORM was my hidden gem of the day. I wondered about DOme, as my second cousin, a civil engineer, was a big fan of Buckminster Fuller.
I was all set to dislike this one but I had a EARTH half way through, certainly not a GLIBNESS.  Congratulations on this very fine debut Mr. Brody (and thanks for hanging out with the commentariat!).
Surprisingly I did this whole puzzle without ever figuring out the theme. Looking back, it feels like a NOBRAINER but at least I got there in the end!

I really liked the theme, and the solver overall.  But I got stuck on not knowing "adenine", nor how to spell "aloha oe", and also had "switched gears".  I couldn't find the answer.  Kind of a natick IMO.  One letter wrong you can just keep guessing until you find it, but I had no idea how many I had wrong and "switches gears" seemed to fit the cluing just fine.  Small nit to pick, but indicating somehow that "switched" in the past tense was preferred would have facilitated this solve considerably for me.

I love the experience of thinking I know some answers, then realizing I don't then- full circle towards the end- feeling grateful to be reminded that there are indeed other ways of looking at things, often much lighter and refreshing than I initially thought or would have come up with on my own. It's refreshing to Switch Gears and Open Doors to new perspectives. Thanks for this reminder!
So wanted HARM POET there! (MIXED METAPHOR)

Did the puzzle. Read Caitlin‚Äôs column. Still don‚Äôt get it.
Luckily, tomorrow is Monday:)

Nice one. And I was especially pleased that 37D was NOT xxxGPT (as it threatened to be since I  initially had 60A as CPI for Consumer Price Index). Newest versions of Microsoft Word and Excel and Gmail keep popping up offers to use AI that aren't any help that I can see.
Wow, really impressive! The long anagrams were duly daunting even after I'd worked out how to solve those clues, but they did come tother over time. Great job!

‚ÄúDesirable formation for ducks‚Äù 

I confidently entered VEE.  üòÄ

And it stayed there for a long time.

I had to let Sam Brody know just how delightful I found his puzzle! Lots of tricky clues, but they all produced smiles and head nods - not a groaner or an eyeroll in the bunch. Great job and hope to see more from you soon!

Did not get the trick of this puzzle at all, so it was basically just a giant crossword puzzle with a lot of trivia. After reading Sam‚Äôs column and looking back at each of the theme answers‚Ä¶ WOW! Just so amazing that someone was able to figure all this out. Unfortunately, re-scrambling or unscrambling letters to make new words is my absolute kryptonite‚Ä¶ I‚Äôve always been just horrible at it. But that doesn‚Äôt take any of the shine off this puzzle, even if I can only enjoy it after the fact.

Loved the puzzle, including the anagrams. So many great clues, including 31A (although I was bummed that it didn't turn out to be tailor-made for Andrezj). My late father, as an alum, would have loved 51A. As much as I loved the clues and the anagrams, though, I think I'm perhaps most impressed by the fact that there have been (as I'm typing this) almost no negative comments! That is a huge accomplishment, so congratulations, Sam! I'm looking forward to solving more of your puzzles.
Cute theme but rather generic puzzle for the rest of the fill.

I'm new to "anagrinds" and although the ones used in this puzzle make sense now (I had to look up anagrind) it seems a bit of an "out" for a puzzle maker to use if they can't come up with an actual anagram instead. I'm sure the more experienced "solvers" out there are familiar with it, but I can't help but put it in the bucket with "rebus" solutions as one of my least favorite things to encounter in a puzzle. :)

My usual late puzzle find. Never seen another like this. A Sunday from November 30, 2008 by Richard Silvestri with the title "Uh-Oh." PERSIANROGUE And some other theme answers: FRIARTOKE PAININTHEBOAT Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/30/2008&g=62&d=D ....

Please don't change the NYT Crossword into a cryptic. I could subscribe to the Times of London if I wanted that.

Congratulations to Sam, a wonderful puzzle maker I have been following for a while.  Not only is it Sam's first entry to the NYT, but it is my first time playing here, so I'm delighted we could share our "firsts."  This puzzle was a lot of fun interspersed with a lot of head scratching! One of my favorites was who revealed the man behind the curtain and my mind went straight to the old "What's My Line" game show and tried so hard to think of the host's name.  When I realized it was Toto from the Wizard of Oz, I actually laughed out loud at myself (and Sam).  There are too many great things about this puzzle to mention here, but it is a very cleverly made puzzle, so hats off to you, Sam.
Polish language. Not sure if this was its first appearance, but what a great clue.

Is there a place (is this the place?) to discuss the monthly crossword? I nodded at ERRS for cluing basketball with ball in Catch Phrase - I don't know that game, but it's a solid rule and, of course, one that I'd taken to apply to the NYT crossword. So I was particularly surprised to see "Workers safety org" cluing OSHA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration!

Finished using crosses ! Did not realize I had been "anagrind ed". Per the rules of Puzzledom, am I nevertheless permitted to brag "TADA" to my wife or must I admit " A blind squirrel often ........." ?

Great fun anyway

One thing hung me up at the end: tenses. I had SWITCHES GEARS because the clue seemed to be in the present tense. When I changed one of the S's to a D, then I had the right DNA base and--voila!--un fait accompli.

"So, is Sara Lee made in Australia? The answer is yes, but with some caveats. Sara Lee has a significant presence in Australia, with several manufacturing facilities and distribution centers across the country. The company‚Äôs Australian operations are headquartered in Sydney, and it employs thousands of people across the country.

Sara Lee‚Äôs Australian product line includes a range of bread and baked goods, such as whole grain bread, white bread, and pastries. The company also manufactures a range of meat and dairy products, including sausages, bacon, and cheese."

Hi CaptainQ,

I've spent some time in the "Pre-Shortz archive" on xwordinfo.com, and I have not encountered a day-by-day difficulty progression with any of the editors. And in the "modern" era only after about 2000.

@Barry Ancona - I have only worked through the archives here, so back only as far as 1993 -- none older than that. I also have not seen a difficulty progression in the older puzzles.

Does the xwordinfo archive go back to the '50s? If so, I might have to subscribe!

CaptainQ, David Steinberg (when he was a child!) and a number of the older commenters here "litzed" every pre-Shortz NYT Crossword to create the archive. You can see them completed or solve them online. It's well worth it. https://www.xwordinfo.com/

@CaptainQuahog

I've been doing the puzzle since the 1960s, when I could get my hands on one and my homework was done, and fairly regularly since the 1990s. I can remember the progressive difficulty through the week as always being a feature of it.

@Teresa - Well, not "always" because if you go to the archives back to the 1990s, the weekly progression is noticeably absent. 

I suspect it was begun in the 1950s and then stopped at some point, and then re-instituted by Shortz.

@M&M (and Teresa" - Bth Barry and I have mentioned that the early Shortz puzzle do NOT have this progression from easy to hard over the week. Here is a passage from Shortz in an interview he did for his alumni magazine in 2005: "Shortz recalls the difficulties of his first year at the Times. His predecessors, Will Weng and Eugene Maleska, had died, so he had no one to go to for advice. He began constructing puzzles based on what he knew as a former Games magazine editor. The regular Times solvers objected, saying the puzzles were for younger people and were too easy. ‚ÄúThey wanted hard puzzles,‚Äù says Shortz, ‚Äúso I thought, by God, if these solvers want hard puzzles I‚Äôll show them how hard it is. I started making everything really hard, then got letters the other way. I then settled into a pattern where the difficulty would increase through the week.‚Äù" There was, in fact, a period of time when this progression was absent. https://www.law.virginia.edu/static/uvalawyer/html/alumni/uvalawyer/f05/shortz.htm
@LBG tough one for me.
@Bill in Yokohama because fads are only hot for a brief period of time

@Bill in Yokohama

My thought is because FADS are only hot for a brief time instead of the usual usage of the word briefly to indicate an abbreviation.

Bill,

You were misdirected by the editors' effort to make the clue easier. You're right: since clue and answer don't have to be true in all cases, it would  be fine to clue FADs just as [Hot things]. Adding [, briefly]  makes it more precise but also -- as you found -- confusing.

Barry,

I'd argue that "Hot" implies brevity, e.g. the Pacer who hits an unusual string of treys, Ohtani's string of lead-off homers, Koh Samui after S3 of White Lotus, etc.

Because the answer was not an abbreviation, I think the clue was actually redundant.

This answer resurfaced a regularly occurring unpopular opinion of mine. That is, if you‚Äôre an app/online solver and get the dreaded ‚ÄúGrrr Keep Trying‚Äù after a complete fill, then you should not get a gold star. 

There, I said it. Perhaps others have previously as well. 

This one would have gotten me today, as would have snarfed v. my entry of scarfed earlier this week.

Maybe there is an additional layer of award that makes the distinction of 100% accuracy on the first try. Kind of like how Marriott keeps changing their status levels. Sigh.

I know people love their gold stars and their precious (and braggadocious) streaks. I do too. And I acknowledge that large thumbs on small phone screens can lead to errors. However, if this were a competition‚Äîthinking the old pen and paper days‚Äîthen these instances would constitute a losing entry. 

I don‚Äôt feel as passionately about this as I do about Chicago trains not being ‚ÄúEls‚Äù (they are ‚ÄúLs‚Äù) but it is getting close.

Anyway, I digress. Congrats to the constructor. Enjoyable puzzle and another gold star* for me.

@DJ

I personally don‚Äôt care about gold stars and streaks. But if you want to have a platinum level for being right on the first time that‚Äôs ok with me. I almost always finish without additional help but frequently have typos and brain glitches so would miss it a lot. Maybe a solution would be a user‚Äôs suggestion below‚Äîa submit button so that you decide when you are done and can check your work before. Unfortunately, neither stops people looking up things‚Äîbut as I said, I don‚Äôt care about gold stars and if your enjoyment of puzzles involves looking up answers, have at it!

@DJ Perhaps someone can revoke your undeserved stars? Maybe try contacting nytgames@nytimes.com. As for other folks' stars, that's up to them. But I agree with you. If I finish with even one box incorrectly filled---end of streak. What I wish we had is a submit button. Too often I fill my last box without realizing it's the last one---and before I've had a chance to review my grid for possible mistakes. (If I remember at the start, I intentionally leave the NW-most box empty, to compensate for the missing submit button.)

@DJ

If you want a platinum level, I can see that. But not changing the gold star rules midstream. When I started my streak several years ago, I accepted the rules as given by the site: asking for an answer invalidates the streak, but being informed that something is wrong somewhere in the puzzle and then finding it on your own does not. With this in mind, my personal rule is not to do a search on a clue, because that seems an end run around the rules, as implemented. 

Adopting competition rules implies adding competition stress. On Sunday morning I'm not looking for that, I'm looking for relaxation along with fun mental exercise. For the same reason, I don't solve these as fast as I can. I see my streak as a marker of dedication and completion, not of perfection.

Maybe there is a way we can both have our wishes. But if the current rules got changed to be more stress/competition-oriented several years into my streak, I would not be a happy camper.

A traffic cone.

@Oikofuge

The reference is to a traffic CONE, I believe.  

When I was tested for my motorcycle license, I had to ride in and out around a series of traffic CONES.

Next, I was told to ride around a block with no one watching.  

I guess they passed me for coming back in one piece.

Does anyone else often call a traffic CONE a PYLON?
I see some evidence it is more a Canadianism, others say North American.

Thanks. Traffic CONEs were all I could think of, but they don't seem like the sort of obstacles that would feature in the "obstacle courses" I know, which have walls and ditches and rope nets---obstacles to be surmounted, rather than ambled round. The name also seems, these days, to be applied to inflatable indoor equivalents.
The motorcycle steering test involving navigating cones is called the "slalom test" in the UK.

So is a winding layout of traffic cones, around which one drives or cycles, called an "obstacle course"?

@Oikofuge

I don't remember a specific name for that part of the test, but in a broad sense, it's a course around obstacles.
@Oikofuge https://www.youtube.com/shorts/a4-SdAemPeE

@JohnWM

My husband who is a civil engineer calls them pylons. It‚Äôs a point of contention for us because, etymologically, a pylon is something flanking an opening or a gate (œÄ·ø†ÃÅŒªŒ∑ in Ancient Greek) which, to me, should not be interchangeable with a traffic cone, which can stand solo. Pylons definitely imply dome thing on both sides of an entryway or a passageway, not just something meant to alert you. Think the pylorus connecting the stomach and the duodenum. Or Thermopylae. 

Or this line from Sophocles‚Äôs Antigone which references the seven gates of Thebes:

·ºëœÄœÑ·Ω∞ ŒªŒøœáŒ±Œ≥Œø·Ω∂ Œ≥·Ω∞œÅ ·ºêœÜ º ·ºëœÄœÑ·Ω∞ œÄœçŒªŒ±ŒπœÇ

Hepta lochagoi gar eph‚Äô hepta pylais: 

Seven captains at seven gates.  (pylais is the dative plural of p√Ωlƒì, gate).

@JohnW
Pylons are typically taller, such as the 50 foot
pylons marking turns in the National 
Championship Air Races at Reno, NV.
The NCAR will be held in Roswell NM this year
because of safety concerns at Reno.
32 people have died in these races since the '60s.
An extremely dangerous sport for pilots and
spectators alike.

@Nancy J.

I guess that's my usage problem. "A course around obstacles" is just a "marked course" in my mental lexicon, because these cones are not really significant obstacles.
For me, an "obstacle course" is a course over, through, or under obstacles---that was the sense used in the sort of "obstacle races" we had at school. And going around those obstacles was very much discouraged!

I'm not claiming my usage is the "correct" one--- but it does explain why CONE was filled grudgingly, on the crosses, because I could't see relevance.

Thank you Sam Lyons & replay, for your perspectives and information. 

Learning now that the word originally meant something like ‚Äúa doorway including both side pillars‚Äù, but also until today only knowing it in terms of not-necessarily-paired traffic cones, bridge and power-line supports, or (yes, paired) airplane wing parts, I think the horse has left the gate on preserving only the original sense.

@Laura
Maybe what's confusing you is that the theme clues (in this puzzle, in all-caps) don't match the theme answers in a traditional way. This is not unusual in Thursday and Sunday NYT crosswords. Part of the puzzle is figuring out "the trick."

The theme clues here are anagrams (words that can make different words when the letters are reordered). You can reorder the letters in the word EARTH to make a new word: HEART. So the first part of the answer to 39-Across, CHANGE OF [HEART], is another way of describing the process of resequencing the letters in the clue [EARTH]. We've CHANGEd the order of letters. 

If and when that makes sense, now look at the other theme clues and answers and see how there's a similar relationship of doing something different to make something new. The letters in each theme clue appear in a different sequence somewhere in the matching answer. 

Does that help?

@MarkInTheMountains

I hadn't heard the term anagrind before either, but as I understand it,  the anagrind indicates the likelihood of an anagram. It doesn't imply that they aren't actually anagrams.

In this case, the constructor clearly did come up with actual anagrams. 

You have every right to dislike them in a puzzle, of course, but I can't see how this could possibly be an out for the constructor. Maybe it's just something you don't like.

@MarkInTheMountains

Had never heard of "anagrinds" until today---seems like an ugly word for a very old concept I'm used to calling "anagram indicators", of which there must be well over a hundred in use in cryptic-style crosswords in the UK.
As I said in a post last night, finding these in [a slightly unconventional] use here in the NYT gave me a warm sense of homecoming.

De gustibus ...
